text: - Hi folks.
This is Shikha Verma.

I'm the head of product
for Amazon DataZone
and I'm here to tell you a little bit more

about how to use Amazon
DataZone to unlock data
across your organization.

Let's start with thinking about
the themes of what we hear

from our customers about
the problems that they run

into when using data to
make business decisions.

The first challenge really
is data is everywhere.

Finding and trusting
data is hard, especially
as data is spread across a variety

of data sources on-prem
as well as in the cloud

and is owned by multiple
teams and organizations.

The second problem is
getting access to this data.

Data is owned by
different people, governed
by different policies.
So even if you find the data,
getting access to it can be cumbersome.

Once you find the data
and get access to it,

using the right tools
of your choice is hard

because people want to use
different kinds of tools.

Analysts, engineers and
data scientists all have

different types of tools
that they want to use
with their data.

The next problem is probably
the biggest one that we have

where there isn't a
collaborative way for data people

like analysts, scientists,
and data engineers to

work together with the same
consistent rules and data sets
that they want to use together.

Last but not the least,
because data is spread
across a variety of sources,

it's used by a variety of
people and a variety of tools.
Data governance is hardest.
Let's root this in a particular example.

I've used this example with
a few customers, which is

around sales campaign
data analysis in order to
focus your dollars on the right products

and the right customers
for your sales campaigns.

The data resides across sales
systems, finance systems,

marketing systems, and comes
in the form of data warehouses
or data lakes.

It's spread across a variety
of different technical
and organizational footprints.

The analysts from sales, marketing
and finance teams need to
use this data

in order to create the
right campaigns to focus on.
Where do this even start?

The first problem of finding
this data across this plethora
of data sources and systems is hard,

when even when they find the
data, who owns this data?
Finding the right owners for the data,
getting access to it is hard.

And then all of these
analysts and engineers
and scientists want to use different kinds
of tools with the same data set.
That is super hard.
After getting access to all of this,
How do you even make sure

that you're governing your
sales data and your revenue data

with the same organizational
guardrails that you're
supposed to follow is the hardest.

So how do we approach and
solve this with DataZone?
Let's look into it a little bit.

Amazon DataZone provides
you one place to go

to where you can catalog and
share your data and govern it

with the same policies across
a variety of teams and tools.
So what that allows us to do

in the same example that
we talked about earlier

is your sales analysts,
your marketing analysts

and engineers, and your
finance folks can come
to the same data portal for DataZone

and start their data journey
by using a simple search bar.
They can look for sales and list pops up.
They can click on the data sets
and find out more information about it.
If that looks like the right data set

they request access to
it from DataZone itself.
Once they get access to it

there's a variety of
tools offered to them.
They can click on any variety

of tools and jump into
the analysis of the data.

They can invite their team
members into the same project.

Now, as you can see, they
were able to find the data.
They were able to get access to it.

They were able to use
the tools of their choice

and they're able to work
with their team members.

All of this within the same
governed environment offered
by Amazon DataZone.

We also recognize that
customers want to use not
just the AWS services and tools
but a variety of other analytics tools to
solve their data management problems.

In order to solve that,
we offer a robust set

of APIs that you can use to
interface with Amazon DataZone
and the core components that it offers.

So let's talk about the
core components a bit.

The first is a business
data catalog, which is

where you organize your data
by your business domains.

You offer your standard
business glossaries,
you add your standard terms.

This is where you publish
all your data assets

and make them available to
your broader organization.

The next is this construct
of data projects.

Data projects is how you bring
your data people together.

This is how we allow
you to govern your data

assets consistently and
govern your tools consistently
for those data assets.

Next is a framework of a
consistent set of governance

and policies that you can
use to manage your data
assets as well as your projects.

All of this comes together
with a unified data portal
which brings your data people,

your data producers, your
consumers, your analysts,

all of them together in
the same unified place
so that that acts as their data homepage.
They can start their journey from there,
share data with whoever they need to

and make this much easier for
organizations than it's today.
So there's three things that I'd

like you to take away
from this conversation.
One is Amazon DataZone is the one place
that all your data people can go to,
to catalog, discover, share, govern

and analyze your data
across your organization.
Second is what used to take you weeks

and months will probably
now take you hours

because we are removing the
undifferentiated heavy lifting
of bringing these pieces together to find

and share your data
across your organization.

And we are building
advanced machine learning

into these modules to
make the automation much
easier for you.

And last but not the least, we
are building Amazon DataZone

as an extensible ecosystem
so that you can use

our APIs to connect Amazon
DataZone very easily

with your homegrown solutions
or with other analytics tools

and solutions that you
use in your organizations.

And with that, thank you
for your time and I am very

excited to see what you will
build using Amazon DataZone.
